prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Lord Henry: Charming, cynical, and eloquent, Lord Henry is a master of witty and provocative speech. He often uses aphorisms and paradoxes, speaking with an air of superiority and a sharp, analytical mind that challenges social norms.
Dorian Gray: A charming but troubled man, Dorian speaks with eloquence and allure, often hiding his inner turmoil behind a façade of beauty and grace. His dialogue can be manipulative or philosophical, reflecting his deep obsession with youth and the consequences of his actions.
Duchess Of Monmouth: A fashionable and aristocratic woman, the Duchess speaks in a polished, formal manner. She is often seen discussing social affairs with elegance, her words carefully chosen to maintain her high status.


Dialogue History: Lord Henry: Like all good reputations, Gladys, Every effect that one produces gives one an enemy. To be popular one must be a mediocrity.
Duchess Of Monmouth: Not with women, and women rule the world. I assure you we can t bear mediocrities. We women, as some one says, love with our ears, just as you men love with your eyes, if you ever love at all.
Dorian Gray: It seems to me that we never do anything else,
Duchess Of Monmouth: Ah! then, you never really love, Mr. Gray,
Lord Henry: My dear Gladys! How can you say that? Romance lives by repetition, and repetition converts an appetite into an art. Besides, each time that one loves is the only time one has ever loved. Difference of object does not alter singleness of passion. It merely intensifies it. We can have in life but one great experience at best, and the secret of life is to reproduce that experience as often as possible.
Duchess Of Monmouth: Even when one has been wounded by it, Harry?
Lord Henry: Especially when one has been wounded by it,
Duchess Of Monmouth: What do you say to that, Mr. Gray?
Dorian Gray: I always agree with Harry, Duchess.
Duchess Of Monmouth: Even when he is wrong?

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Dorian Gray: Harry is never wrong, Duchess.

Dialogue History: Lord Fermor: Well, Harry, what brings you out so early? I thought you dandies never got up till two, and were not visible till five.
Lord Henry: Pure family affection, I assure you, Uncle George. I want to get something out of you.
Lord Fermor: Money, I suppose, Well, sit down and tell me all about it. Young people, nowadays, imagine that money is everything.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Lord Henry: Yes, and when they grow older they know it. But I don t want money. It is only people who pay their bills who want that, Uncle George, and I never pay mine. Credit is the capital of a younger son, and one lives charmingly upon it. Besides, I always deal with Dartmoor s tradesmen, and consequently they never bother me. What I want is information: not useful information, of course; useless information.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Lord Henry: Charming, cynical, and eloquent, Lord Henry is a master of witty and provocative speech. He often uses aphorisms and paradoxes, speaking with an air of superiority and a sharp, analytical mind that challenges social norms.
Mr. Erskine: A polite but somewhat unremarkable character, Mr. Erskine’s speech is courteous and professional. He tends to be formal and polite, though his words often lack depth or passion.
Sir Thomas Burdon: A dignified and somewhat pompous figure, Sir Thomas speaks with authority and self-assuredness. His dialogue is often laced with condescension, as he believes in his superior knowledge and social position.
Lady Agatha: An aristocratic woman of high status, Lady Agatha is elegant and refined. Her speech reflects her sophistication, and she is often involved in social causes, speaking with passion when it comes to matters of charity or society.
Mrs. Vandeleur: A woman of wealth and stature, Mrs. Vandeleur is refined and proper. Her speech is polite and often carries a hint of condescension, reflecting her elevated social position.
Lord Fermor: A senior, somewhat cynical aristocrat, Lord Fermor speaks in a dry, often sarcastic manner. His dialogue carries an air of old-fashioned privilege, and he can be blunt when expressing his opinions.
Duchess Of Harley: A lively, social figure, the Duchess is full of energy and enthusiasm. Her speech is engaging and often humorous, reflecting her interest in gossip and the latest happenings in high society.
Dorian Gray: A charming but troubled man, Dorian speaks with eloquence and allure, often hiding his inner turmoil behind a façade of beauty and grace. His dialogue can be manipulative or philosophical, reflecting his deep obsession with youth and the consequences of his actions.


Dialogue History: Sir Thomas Burdon: I do not understand you,
Mr. Erskine: I do, Lord Henry,
Sir Thomas Burdon: Paradoxes are all very well in their way....
Mr. Erskine: Was that a paradox? I did not think so. Perhaps it was. Well, the way of paradoxes is the way of truth. To test reality we must see it on the tight rope. When the verities become acrobats, we can judge them.
Lady Agatha: Dear me! how you men argue! I am sure I never can make out what you are talking about. Oh! Harry, I am quite vexed with you. Why do you try to persuade our nice Mr. Dorian Gray to give up the East End? I assure you he would be quite invaluable. They would love his playing.
Lord Henry: I want him to play to me,
Lady Agatha: But they are so unhappy in Whitechapel,
Lord Henry: I can sympathize with everything except suffering, I cannot sympathize with that. It is too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid in the modern sympathy with pain. One should sympathize with the colour, the beauty, the joy of life. The less said about life s sores, the better.
Sir Thomas Burdon: Still, the East End is a very important problem,
Lord Henry: Quite so, It is the problem of slavery, and we try to solve it by amusing the slaves.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Sir Thomas Burdon: What change do you propose, then?

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar: A carefree, flirtatious individual, this woman is often found indulging in gossip and enjoying herself. Her speech is lively and unrestrained, marked by a tendency to speak candidly and openly.
Adrian Singleton: A melancholic and somewhat self-destructive man, Adrian speaks with a sense of regret and hopelessness. His dialogue reflects his inner turmoil and disillusionment with life, often tinged with sadness and cynicism.
Hansom Driver: A blunt, no-nonsense character, the Hansom Driver speaks in short, practical sentences. His dialogue is often direct, with a focus on his job rather than pleasantries or social niceties.
James Vane: A passionate and vengeful character, James Vane speaks with intensity and emotion. His dialogue is often marked by a sense of urgency and a desire for justice, especially in matters concerning his sister, Sibyl.
One Of The Women: A lively and slightly flirtatious character, this woman often speaks in an open and candid manner. She is quick to offer an opinion, especially when discussing the latest trends or social events.
Dorian Gray: A charming but troubled man, Dorian speaks with eloquence and allure, often hiding his inner turmoil behind a façade of beauty and grace. His dialogue can be manipulative or philosophical, reflecting his deep obsession with youth and the consequences of his actions.


Dialogue History: James Vane: You had better confess your sin, for as sure as I am James Vane, you are going to die.
James Vane: Down on your knees! I give you one minute to make your peace no more. I go on board to-night for India, and I must do my job first. One minute. That s all.
Dorian Gray: Stop, How long ago is it since your sister died? Quick, tell me!
James Vane: Eighteen years, Why do you ask me? What do years matter?
Dorian Gray: Eighteen years, Eighteen years! Set me under the lamp and look at my face!
James Vane: My God! my God! and I would have murdered you!
Dorian Gray: You have been on the brink of committing a terrible crime, my man, Let this be a warning to you not to take vengeance into your own hands.
James Vane: Forgive me, sir, I was deceived. A chance word I heard in that damned den set me on the wrong track.
Dorian Gray: You had better go home and put that pistol away, or you may get into trouble,
One Of The Women Who Had Been Drinking At The Bar: Why didn t you kill him? I knew you were following him when you rushed out from Daly s. You fool! You should have killed him. He has lots of money, and he s as bad as bad.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: James Vane: He is not the man I am looking for, and I want no man s money. I want a man s life. The man whose life I want must be nearly forty now. This one is little more than a boy. Thank God, I have not got his blood upon my hands.

[INST] Character Info: Lord Henry: Charming, cynical, and eloquent, Lord Henry is a master of witty and provocative speech. He often uses aphorisms and paradoxes, speaking with an air of superiority and a sharp, analytical mind that challenges social norms.
Mr. Erskine: A polite but somewhat unremarkable character, Mr. Erskine’s speech is courteous and professional. He tends to be formal and polite, though his words often lack depth or passion.

Lady Agatha: An aristocratic woman of high status, Lady Agatha is elegant and refined. Her speech reflects her sophistication, and she is often involved in social causes, speaking with passion when it comes to matters of charity or society.
Mrs. Vandeleur: A woman of wealth and stature, Mrs. Vandeleur is refined and proper. Her speech is polite and often carries a hint of condescension, reflecting her elevated social position.
Lord Fermor: A senior, somewhat cynical aristocrat, Lord Fermor speaks in a dry, often sarcastic manner. His dialogue carries an air of old-fashioned privilege, and he can be blunt when expressing his opinions.
Duchess Of Harley: A lively, social figure, the Duchess is full of energy and enthusiasm. Her speech is engaging and often humorous, reflecting her interest in gossip and the latest happenings in high society.
Dorian Gray: A charming but troubled man, Dorian speaks with eloquence and allure, often hiding his inner turmoil behind a façade of beauty and grace. His dialogue can be manipulative or philosophical, reflecting his deep obsession with youth and the consequences of his actions.


Dialogue History: Duchess Of Harley: Oh! but I have seen specimens of the inhabitants, I must confess that most of them are extremely pretty. And they dress well, too. They get all their dresses in Paris. I wish I could afford to do the same.
Sir Thomas Burdon: They say that when good Americans die they go to Paris,
Duchess Of Harley: Really! And where do bad Americans go to when they die?
Lord Henry: They go to America,
Sir Thomas Burdon: I am afraid that your nephew is prejudiced against that great country, I have travelled all over it in cars provided by the directors, who, in such matters, are extremely civil. I assure you that it is an education to visit it.
Mr. Erskine: But must we really see Chicago in order to be educated? I don t feel up to the journey.
Sir Thomas Burdon: Mr. Erskine of Treadley has the world on his shelves. We practical men like to see things, not to read about them. The Americans are an extremely interesting people. They are absolutely reasonable. I think that is their distinguishing characteristic. Yes, Mr. Erskine, an absolutely reasonable people. I assure you there is no nonsense about the Americans.
Lord Henry: How dreadful! I can stand brute force, but brute reason is quite unbearable. There is something unfair about its use. It is hitting below the intellect.
Sir Thomas Burdon: I do not understand you,
Mr. Erskine: I do, Lord Henry,

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Sir Thomas Burdon: Paradoxes are all very well in their way....

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Francis: A quiet and loyal character, Francis speaks with respect and a touch of hesitation. His words are measured and often reflect his sense of duty and devotion to his work or those he serves.
Alan Campbell: An intelligent and conflicted man, Alan Campbell is reserved but speaks with conviction. His words reflect a struggle between his scientific mind and moral values, often hinting at deeper internal turmoil.
Dorian Gray: A charming but troubled man, Dorian speaks with eloquence and allure, often hiding his inner turmoil behind a façade of beauty and grace. His dialogue can be manipulative or philosophical, reflecting his deep obsession with youth and the consequences of his actions.


Dialogue History: Dorian Gray: Do you still refuse to do this for me?
Alan Campbell: Of course I refuse. I will have absolutely nothing to do with it. I don t care what shame comes on you. You deserve it all. I should not be sorry to see you disgraced, publicly disgraced. How dare you ask me, of all men in the world, to mix myself up in this horror? I should have thought you knew more about people s characters. Your friend Lord Henry Wotton can t have taught you much about psychology, whatever else he has taught you. Nothing will induce me to stir a step to help you. You have come to the wrong man. Go to some of your friends. Don t come to me.
Dorian Gray: Alan, it was murder. I killed him. You don t know what he had made me suffer. Whatever my life is, he had more to do with the making or the marring of it than poor Harry has had. He may not have intended it, the result was the same.
Alan Campbell: Murder! Good God, Dorian, is that what you have come to? I shall not inform upon you. It is not my business. Besides, without my stirring in the matter, you are certain to be arrested. Nobody ever commits a crime without doing something stupid. But I will have nothing to do with it.
Dorian Gray: You must have something to do with it. Wait, wait a moment; listen to me. Only listen, Alan. All I ask of you is to perform a certain scientific experiment. You go to hospitals and dead-houses, and the horrors that you do there don t affect you. If in some hideous dissecting-room or fetid laboratory you found this man lying on a leaden table with red gutters scooped out in it for the blood to flow through, you would simply look upon him as an admirable subject. You would not turn a hair. You would not believe that you were doing anything wrong. On the contrary, you would probably feel that you were benefiting the human race, or increasing the sum of knowledge in the world, or gratifying intellectual curiosity, or something of that kind. What I want you to do is merely what you have often done before. Indeed, to destroy a body must be far less horrible than what you are accustomed to work at. And, remember, it is the only piece of evidence against me. If it is discovered, I am lost; and it is sure to be discovered unless you help me.
Alan Campbell: I have no desire to help you. You forget that. I am simply indifferent to the whole thing. It has nothing to do with me.
Dorian Gray: Alan, I entreat you. Think of the position I am in. Just before you came I almost fainted with terror. You may know terror yourself some day. No! don t think of that. Look at the matter purely from the scientific point of view. You don t inquire where the dead things on which you experiment come from. Don t inquire now. I have told you too much as it is. But I beg of you to do this. We were friends once, Alan.
Alan Campbell: Don t speak about those days, Dorian they are dead.
Dorian Gray: The dead linger sometimes. The man upstairs will not go away. He is sitting at the table with bowed head and outstretched arms. Alan! Alan! If you don t come to my assistance, I am ruined. Why, they will hang me, Alan! Don t you understand? They will hang me for what I have done.
Alan Campbell: There is no good in prolonging this scene. I absolutely refuse to do anything in the matter. It is insane of you to ask me.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]

[INST] Character Info: Lord Henry: Charming, cynical, and eloquent, Lord Henry is a master of witty and provocative speech. He often uses aphorisms and paradoxes, speaking with an air of superiority and a sharp, analytical mind that challenges social norms.
Lady Henry: A quiet but dignified woman, Lady Henry’s speech is measured and composed. While she might appear reserved, her tone reveals a deep understanding of social propriety and the nuances of high society.
Dorian Gray: A charming but troubled man, Dorian speaks with eloquence and allure, often hiding his inner turmoil behind a façade of beauty and grace. His dialogue can be manipulative or philosophical, reflecting his deep obsession with youth and the consequences of his actions.


Dialogue History: Dorian Gray: Why, Harry?
Lord Henry: Because they are so sentimental.
Dorian Gray: But I like sentimental people.
Lord Henry: Never marry at all, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women, because they are curious: both are disappointed.
Dorian Gray: I don t think I am likely to marry, Harry. I am too much in love. That is one of your aphorisms. I am putting it into practice, as I do everything that you say.
Lord Henry: Who are you in love with?
Dorian Gray: With an actress,
Lord Henry: That is a rather commonplace _d but_.
Dorian Gray: You would not say so if you saw her, Harry.
Lord Henry: Who is she?

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Dorian Gray: Her name is Sibyl Vane.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Lord Henry: Charming, cynical, and eloquent, Lord Henry is a master of witty and provocative speech. He often uses aphorisms and paradoxes, speaking with an air of superiority and a sharp, analytical mind that challenges social norms.
Mr. Erskine: A polite but somewhat unremarkable character, Mr. Erskine’s speech is courteous and professional. He tends to be formal and polite, though his words often lack depth or passion.
Sir Thomas Burdon: A dignified and somewhat pompous figure, Sir Thomas speaks with authority and self-assuredness. His dialogue is often laced with condescension, as he believes in his superior knowledge and social position.
Lady Agatha: An aristocratic woman of high status, Lady Agatha is elegant and refined. Her speech reflects her sophistication, and she is often involved in social causes, speaking with passion when it comes to matters of charity or society.
Mrs. Vandeleur: A woman of wealth and stature, Mrs. Vandeleur is refined and proper. Her speech is polite and often carries a hint of condescension, reflecting her elevated social position.
Lord Fermor: A senior, somewhat cynical aristocrat, Lord Fermor speaks in a dry, often sarcastic manner. His dialogue carries an air of old-fashioned privilege, and he can be blunt when expressing his opinions.
Duchess Of Harley: A lively, social figure, the Duchess is full of energy and enthusiasm. Her speech is engaging and often humorous, reflecting her interest in gossip and the latest happenings in high society.
Dorian Gray: A charming but troubled man, Dorian speaks with eloquence and allure, often hiding his inner turmoil behind a façade of beauty and grace. His dialogue can be manipulative or philosophical, reflecting his deep obsession with youth and the consequences of his actions.


Dialogue History: Lord Fermor: Well, Harry, what brings you out so early? I thought you dandies never got up till two, and were not visible till five.
Lord Henry: Pure family affection, I assure you, Uncle George. I want to get something out of you.
Lord Fermor: Money, I suppose, Well, sit down and tell me all about it. Young people, nowadays, imagine that money is everything.
Lord Henry: Yes, and when they grow older they know it. But I don t want money. It is only people who pay their bills who want that, Uncle George, and I never pay mine. Credit is the capital of a younger son, and one lives charmingly upon it. Besides, I always deal with Dartmoor s tradesmen, and consequently they never bother me. What I want is information: not useful information, of course; useless information.
Lord Fermor: Well, I can tell you anything that is in an English Blue Book, Harry, although those fellows nowadays write a lot of nonsense. When I was in the Diplomatic, things were much better. But I hear they let them in now by examination. What can you expect? Examinations, sir, are pure humbug from beginning to end. If a man is a gentleman, he knows quite enough, and if he is not a gentleman, whatever he knows is bad for him.
Lord Henry: Mr. Dorian Gray does not belong to Blue Books, Uncle George,
Lord Fermor: Mr. Dorian Gray? Who is he?

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Lord Henry: That is what I have come to learn, Uncle George. Or rather, I know who he is. He is the last Lord Kelso s grandson. His mother was a Devereux, Lady Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about his mother. What was she like? Whom did she marry? You have known nearly everybody in your time, so you might have known her. I am very much interested in Mr. Gray at present. I have only just met him.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Lord Henry: Charming, cynical, and eloquent, Lord Henry is a master of witty and provocative speech. He often uses aphorisms and paradoxes, speaking with an air of superiority and a sharp, analytical mind that challenges social norms.
Basil Hallward: A sincere and introspective artist, Basil speaks with genuine affection and admiration, especially toward Dorian. His dialogue is often earnest, thoughtful, and tinged with the melancholy of unspoken feelings.
Dorian Gray: A charming but troubled man, Dorian speaks with eloquence and allure, often hiding his inner turmoil behind a façade of beauty and grace. His dialogue can be manipulative or philosophical, reflecting his deep obsession with youth and the consequences of his actions.


Dialogue History: Dorian Gray: You must lend me these, Basil, I want to learn them. They are perfectly charming.
Basil Hallward: That entirely depends on how you sit to-day, Dorian.
Dorian Gray: Oh, I am tired of sitting, and I don t want a life-sized portrait of myself,
Dorian Gray: I beg your pardon, Basil, but I didn t know you had any one with you.
Basil Hallward: This is Lord Henry Wotton, Dorian, an old Oxford friend of mine. I have just been telling him what a capital sitter you were, and now you have spoiled everything.
Lord Henry: You have not spoiled my pleasure in meeting you, Mr. Gray, My aunt has often spoken to me about you. You are one of her favourites, and, I am afraid, one of her victims also.
Dorian Gray: I am in Lady Agatha s black books at present, I promised to go to a club in Whitechapel with her last Tuesday, and I really forgot all about it. We were to have played a duet together three duets, I believe. I don t know what she will say to me. I am far too frightened to call.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Lord Henry: Oh, I will make your peace with my aunt. She is quite devoted to you. And I don t think it really matters about your not being there. The audience probably thought it was a duet. When Aunt Agatha sits down to the piano, she makes quite enough noise for two people.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Sibyl Vane: A delicate, sensitive young woman, Sibyl speaks with innocence and idealism. Her words often reflect her deep emotions, especially when it comes to her love for Dorian Gray, and her dialogue can be filled with youthful passion and vulnerability.
Mrs. Vane: A determined and somewhat overbearing woman, Mrs. Vane is protective of her daughter, Sibyl. She often speaks with intensity, showing both pride and concern for her family's reputation.
James Vane: A passionate and vengeful character, James Vane speaks with intensity and emotion. His dialogue is often marked by a sense of urgency and a desire for justice, especially in matters concerning his sister, Sibyl.


Dialogue History: Mrs. Vane: Happy! I am only happy, Sibyl, when I see you act. You must not think of anything but your acting. Mr. Isaacs has been very good to us, and we owe him money.
Sibyl Vane: Money, Mother? what does money matter? Love is more than money.
Mrs. Vane: Mr. Isaacs has advanced us fifty pounds to pay off our debts and to get a proper outfit for James. You must not forget that, Sibyl. Fifty pounds is a very large sum. Mr. Isaacs has been most considerate.
Sibyl Vane: He is not a gentleman, Mother, and I hate the way he talks to me,
Mrs. Vane: I don t know how we could manage without him,
Sibyl Vane: We don t want him any more, Mother. Prince Charming rules life for us now.
Sibyl Vane: I love him,
Mrs. Vane: Foolish child! foolish child!
Sibyl Vane: Mother, Mother, why does he love me so much? I know why I love him. I love him because he is like what love himself should be. But what does he see in me? I am not worthy of him. And yet why, I cannot tell though I feel so much beneath him, I don t feel humble. I feel proud, terribly proud. Mother, did you love my father as I love Prince Charming?
Sibyl Vane: Forgive me, Mother. I know it pains you to talk about our father. But it only pains you because you loved him so much. Don t look so sad. I am as happy to-day as you were twenty years ago. Ah! let me be happy for ever!

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Mrs. Vane: My child, you are far too young to think of falling in love. Besides, what do you know of this young man? You don t even know his name. The whole thing is most inconvenient, and really, when James is going away to Australia, and I have so much to think of, I must say that you should have shown more consideration. However, as I said before, if he is rich ...
